BE11:21am

Debenhams profit warning
Having previously signalled that the business was on track to
deliver market expectations in January, Debenhams is now
flagging H2 disruption from its restructuring process and
increased finance costs. The forecasts are now largely academic;
we downgrade, but the real story is when the group will launch a
CVA, equity raise and restructuring plan. With no date
confirmed yet for the interim announcement, this is likely to
come sooner rather than later.

BE11:21am

Trading pressure continues, albeit at a slightly improved run rate. LFL sales
are down 4.6% over the final eight weeks of H1, with overall GTV down 5%, a
slight improvement from the 5.6% decline reported for the first 18 weeks of H1.
We expect H1 to be broadly break even (vs prior year PBT of £45m).
Forecast downgrades. Internal expectations are now drifting away from a
market breakeven consensus and a low point of c£10m loss; we downgrade our
full-year loss to £30m, a position exacerbated by fully drawn facilities and the
additional £40m facility that has been taken out. H2 will be impacted by
working capital challenges and general trading disruption before we take account
of any CVA process. Assuming this happens, then 2019/20 becomes a
transitional year of store closures and right-sizing. Our current forecast cuts are
all fairly academic; Debenhams is clearly working towards a longer-term
solution, which we believe will include a CVA and an equity fundraise. With no
date yet confirmed for the interim results next month, we believe management is
working towards being in a position to announce a way forward by the end of
April.

BE11:25am

Let's try Citi.

BE11:25am

 2Q (Jan/Feb) trading saw UK LFL -6%, in-line with the -6.2% reported in SepDec – Debenhams saw overall GTV decline moderate slightly in the last 8 weeks to -5% (from -5.6% in first 18 weeks) with International seeing more of a recovery than the UK. Somewhat worryingly in the UK digital sales growth slowed from +4.6% to +2% in the last two months which is unhelpful given the company focus on the digital channel. The disruption and consumer uncertainty created by this process will likely prove to be a further headwind until it is resolved.
 No longer on track to hit consensus profit numbers – The combination of ongoing weak trading and increased financing costs due to working capital requirements will likely impact the profit forecast to a greater degree. The increased working capital requirement may raise a few alarm bells given discussion of trade credit insurance cover being reduced and the company having to fund the difference. The “annualised” £80m cost saving programme is on track but insufficient to offset the combination of the trading and increased financing costs.
 Discussions to restructure the balance sheet ongoing – Debenhams is still likely to see a significant change in its retail store estate in the next few years. Whilst discussions with landlords are ongoing it may be hard to achieve concessions from local authorities with regards business rates without setting a precedent for the entire market. The most likely outcome in our view remains a CVA to shed the underperforming stores in the most efficient manner. The ability of management to restructure the business and refinance the debt is critical at this stage and the trading performance is unlikely to be the main focus until this is concluded.

BE11:32am

Ibstock has reported FY18 revenues from continuing operations of £391m, up 8% yoy. This translated into EBITDA of £112.4m, representing growth of 4% yoy, and and is in line with our forecast of £112.1m and previous guidance of £110-114m. The key variances versus our forecasts was a better outturn from clay bricks (+11% yoy) offset by a slightly weaker performance from concrete (+1% yoy). Net debt/EBITDA has come in at 0.4x offering clear balance sheet optionality for the medium term.

BE11:32am

With the group net debt/EBITDA now below 0.5x, the focus is on capital allocation. Management has indicated it will invest in sustainable performance, innovation and selective growth including M&A. On the latter, management notes that it will review both bolt-on and transormational M&A where there is a clear strategic fit. To this end, capex will increase to £28-32m in FY19 and FY20 as the group invests in enhancing the group’s operational performance including supply chain optimisation, commercial excellence, and some projects that will enhance capacity in both the brick and concrete facilities. These projects will deliver £5m of EBITDA benefit phased from FY21 onward. There is no guidance on further capital returns which we believe will be a focus on the call and there remains scope to repeat last year’s return at the interim stage in 2019. On outlook, management notes that while there is uncertainty created by Brexit the fundamentals remain positive in the medium-term.

(@Fatdaz: IIRC, you don't get many synergies from bricks. Very local markets, and a very heavy product that doesn't make up much of the cost of actual buildings, so not much in the way of pricing power from concentration.)

11:33 am
BE11:34am

And Davy.

BE11:34am

Ibstock is now fully focused on the UK and with net debt/adjusted EBITDA of just 0.4x has good financial optionality. The latter supported a supplementary dividend last year that brought the effective yield to over 6%. 2018 was a relatively eventful year for Ibstock with the commissioning of a 100m new brick factory (thus adding over 10% to its capacity) and the exit from the US. The group expects another year of progress in 2019 but, not surprisingly, references the current political and economic uncertainties. The stock is up over 25% year-to-date but is little changed over the past 12 months.

FATDAZ @Be fair enough
BE11:34am

Ibstock has announced its 2018 results. In mid-January a trading update indicated that results on a continuing basis, which allows for the disposal in late November of what was the group’s US business, would be in line with expectations. Continuing revenues last year were £391m, up 8% year-on-year (yoy) as previously flagged. Adjusted EBITDA and adjusted EPS were £112.4m (+4% yoy) and 18.8p (-0.5% yoy) respectively. The adjusted EBITDA result is 2% ahead of our £110m forecast.
Net debt at year-end was £48m (Davy forecast: £51m) with net debt/EBITDA at a modest level of 0.4x. A second-half dividend per share (DPS) of 6.5p takes the full-year distribution to 16p (Davy forecast: 14.9p), implying an attractive yield of over 6%. This includes the supplementary DPS of 6.5p.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

There is no meaningful detail in Ibstock’s outlook statement, with the group just noting it is “mindful of the current political and economic uncertainties” but that it looks forward to “another year of progress”. The capacity maintenance programme continues as planned while capital expenditure is expected to be circa £28-32m for 2019 and 2020. This includes enhancement projects with over £5m in adjusted EBITDA benefits to come through from 2021. We currently forecast capital expenditure of under £40m over the next two years.
Operationally, for this year we currently assume organic revenue growth of 4%, split between price and volume, and 8% overall. Our current 2019 EBITDA forecast is £121m, consistent with the consensus estimate (£120m).

BE11:35am

As noted, with the exit from the US, Ibstock is now a fully focused UK business. In the UK last year, clay and concrete revenues were £293m and £98m respectively. The increase in clay revenues (+9% yoy) was boosted by the gradual ramp-up during the year of Ibstock’s new brick factory. Hence revenue growth accelerated to 13% yoy in H1, having increased by 3% yoy in the first half (which was weather affected). Concrete revenues were flat last year due to what was described as a “slight softening in the rail and civils market”.
The UK EBITDA margin – before central costs – fell in 2018 from 30.5% to 29.7%. Higher energy costs were a factor as was the maintenance cost investment.
As previously flagged, Ibstock also generated £9.5m in profit from the disposal of surplus property last year. Reported pre-tax profit was £92.5m while adjusted pre-tax profit was £97.5m.

BE11:47am

Elementis? Sure. Results weak, guidance fine.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

UBS can summarise.

BE11:48am

Q. How did the results compare vs expectations?
Elementis reported 2H18 sales of $406m, 4% below consensus. EBIT was $132m and only marginally below cons in 2H and in-line on an adjusted basis. Adj. EPS was 5% below cons on higher taxes. Cash flow was in-line with our and cons estimates with net debt of $498m at the end of 2018 (UBSe $492m, cons $499m). Net debt to EBITDA finished the year at 3.05x (UBSe 2.9x) or 2.5 adj. and pro forma and we estimate a delivering of one turn by the end of 2019 which is in-line with company guidance for "around 2x" by the end of 2019. The dividend was 8.4c/sh adj. (cons 8.4c/sh).Variance analysis on page 2.

Q. What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
There are two issues that investors are likely to focus on today: 1) Mondo was consolidated for ~10 weeks of the final quarter and initial comments are reassuring with $20-25m of revenue synergies targeted by 2023 (10-15% on FY18 PF Mondo sales), although the business likely got off to a slow start in 2019 (autos) and initial sales contribution of $21.5m was lower than anticipated; 2) 2H EBIT margin was -90 bps YoY in 2H18, against cons of -140bps (UBSe -240 bps) with the beat driven by Chromium where pricing benefits and insurance cover for plant shutdowns more than offset lower volumes. With Specialties falling short of expectations on EBIT and margins, the quality of the earnings mix is somewhat weaker even though the group margin was better than forecast.

Q. Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
Management has issued a general outlook statement saying that, while the market conditions remain challenging, they expect "good progress with focus on Talc integration, self-help initiatives and deleveraging". Consensus models 16% EPS growth on a pre-published cons 2018 base of 17.3p. UBS estimates 18% growth.

Valuation: Trades at unjustified 40% discount to Spec Chems peers, in our view
Our 290p PT would put Elementis at 17x PE on 2019E and FCF yield of 4.3%. The current 11x PE and 8x EV/EBITDA are at a greater than 40% discount to the specialty chemicals peer group, which we see as unjustified given the de-risking of the Chromium business and enhanced platform afforded by the personal care acquisition of 2017.

BE11:49am

And Credit Suisse.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Elementis reported H2 adj. EBIT of $64m 2% below consensus ($65m) and 4% below CS ($67m). The earnings mix was poor in H2 with a miss in Specialty Products offset by a beat in Chromium. Management proposed an ordinary dividend of 8.4c, ahead of CS expectations (8.27c). Guidance is for continued progress in 2019 and long term. FY operating cash $84.3mn vs CS $100m due to higher than expected non-recurring costs. We expect a negative share price reaction given weak mix and cash. ■ Specialty Products – Miss – (H2 EBIT $49m, vs CS $60m). o Personal Care In 2H, cosmetics and AP actives returned to growth, achieving 6% and 5% organic growth respectively yoy. o Coatings - Americas organic revenue growth of +3% (FY basis) due to customer wins. Asia flat (FY basis); decline in low value resins and lower overall activity levels, primarily in China, offset by pricing and mix. EMEA (2)% (FY basis) due deterioration in demand, particularly in 4Q. o Energy - drilling activity levels negatively impacted by infrastructure constraints in North America and a one time inventory reduction as two key customers merged. In 2H 18 activity levels modestly improved with +3% reported revenue growth HoH.

BE11:50am

Chromium –– Beat - (H2 EBIT $19, vs CS $12m). Outages aside (Castle Hayne Feb and Sep), demand levels in North America and the RoW were robust and drove global industry utilisation levels to greater than 90%. As a result, ASP increased 5% on 2017 (FY basis)

BE11:50am

■ Talc – In line – (H2 EBIT $4mn, vs CS $4m). In the two months of ownership, Talc contributed $3.9m of adjusted operating profit (18% margin). On a 12 month constancy currency basis, adjusted operating profit rose 26% to $24.6m as a result of top line growth, better utilisation levels and improved mix.

Oh, peace has broken out at Papa John's: https://www.sec.go...5/a19-5853_18k.htm

BE11:54am

On March 4, 2019, Papa John’s International, Inc., a Delaware Corporation (the “Company”) entered into a Settlement Agreement (the “Settlement Agreement”) with John H. Schnatter. Pursuant to the Settlement Agreement, the Company has agreed to cooperate with Mr. Schnatter to identify a mutually acceptable independent director (an “Independent Designee”). The Independent Designee must meet certain eligibility criteria set forth in the Settlement Agreement, including that the Independent Designee have relevant professional experience and be independent of both Mr. Schnatter and certain funds affiliated with, or managed by, Starboard Value LP (collectively, “Starboard”).

In accordance with the Settlement Agreement, if the Independent Designee is appointed to the Board of Directors (the “Board”) prior to the 2019 Annual Meeting of Stockholders (the “2019 Annual Meeting”), Mr. Schnatter has agreed to resign as a member of the Board effective upon the appointment of the Independent Designee (unless he decides to resign at an earlier time). Otherwise, Mr. Schnatter’s term as a director will expire at the 2019 Annual Meeting.

The Company has agreed, within ten business days of the date of the Settlement Agreement, to (i) amend the Governance Agreement, dated as of February 4, 2019 (the “Governance Agreement”), between the Company and Starboard to remove the provision that would have required Starboard, for a period of time, to vote the shares of the Company’s securities that it beneficially owns in favor of the Board’s director nominees and in accordance with the Board’s recommendations and (ii) amend the Rights Agreement, dated as of July 22, 2018, by and between the Company and Computershare Trust Company, N.A., as rights agent, as amended on February 3, 2019 (as amended, the “Rights Agreement”) to eliminate the “Acting in Concert” definition.

Upon the amendment to the Governance Agreement and Rights Agreement, Mr. Schnatter’s recently submitted nomination of himself to be re-elected to the Board at the 2019 Annual Meeting will be automatically withdrawn. In addition, Mr. Schnatter agreed to (i) cause a Notice of Dismissal to be filed in the action pending in the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware styled, John H. Schnatter v. Mark S. Shapiro, et al., C.A. No. 2018-0646-AGB, dismissing the action without prejudice and (ii) cause the action filed by Evergreen Real Estate, LLC against the Company in the circuit court for Jefferson County, Kentucky related to a sublease agreement to be dismissed with prejudice.

A copy of the Settlement Agreement is filed as Exhibit 10.1 hereto and incorporated herein by reference. The foregoing description of the Settlement Agreement does not purport to be complete and is qualified in its entirety by reference to the complete text of the Settlement Agreement.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

GVC has just published strong 2018 numbers and indications: On a pro-
forma basis, underlying EBITDA came in at the top of the guided range [GBP750m-755m], up 13% yoy, with group net gaming revenues (NGR) up
8% yoy [+19% yoy in digital]. Online brands grew market share in all
territories, with the UK now representing 36% of digital revenues, net debt
at year end reached GBP1,897m (2.5x EBITDA), the dividend for the full
year was GBp32 per share and progressive the dividend policy is at least
+10% per year (we expected +6% previously). Tax assessment with the
Greek authorities entails an additional cash-out of c£85m in 2019, relative
to the years 2012-17.

BE12:04pm

● 2019 started with NGR up 11% yoy and digital up 22%: GVC keeps reporting
excellent operational trends. Even in the period of 1 January-24 February
2019, the company’s NGR went up 11% yoy, with UK retail down 2%,
European retail up 9% and digital up 22% yoy. Digital growth rates remain
the jewel in GVC’s crown. We think that the UK business is likely to have
double-digit growth, too, which is quite extraordinary given the slowdown in
the market. We expect this to be confirmed by Paddy Power and TheStars’
results tomorrow, and was hinted at in William Hill’s presentation last week.
As we have flagged in our recent note Share weakness offers unique entry
point (dated 28 February 2019), GVC’s UK digital business is now trading
implicitly on c4x 2020E EBITDA, on conservative estimates.

BE12:04pm

US opportunity to be discussed at the analyst meeting, positive language
on the Playtech agreement: Details of the US opportunity will be given at

the company’s analyst meeting later today (we believe our expected start-
up losses of c£35m in 2019 are quite aggressive). The just-renegotiated

Playtech agreement entails that GVC could internalise its platform sooner
than the planned date of 2021, and it has indeed “commenced planning on
this basis”. We estimate that the gross pre-tax saving from switching
platforms could amount to cGBP40m – should this take place in 2020, it
would mean a high single-digit positive impact on 2020E adjusted EPS.
● We see upside risk to FY consensus expectations: The company states
that it is confident about meeting expectations for 2019 (consensus
EBITDA: GBP640m). We appreciate it is very early in the year, and that the
substantial changes in UK retail create a degree of uncertainty. However,
top-line evolution in the first eight weeks, as well as the operational
leverage in the business, suggest that consensus numbers are on the
conservative side. GVC will hold a capital markets day on 16 May.

BE12:06pm

GVC closed out FY18 in line with guidance. Current trading is "excellent" with
online NGR +22%. It trades on 9.0x FY19e EV/EBITDA and a dividend yield of 5.0%,
we reiterate our BUY recommendation.
● Key financials: GVC reported FY18 EBITDA of £755m (Nse £754m), in line with
January's upgraded management guidance of £750-755m. EPS of 76p (NSe 76p) and
DPS of 32p (32p) were in line with our estimates. As previously reported, pro-forma
revenue grew 9% to £3571m (£3574m) with online the stand-out division growing 21%,
evenly split between sports (+22%) and games brands (+16%). UK retail LFL revenue
fell 3% yoy (vs. WMH -2%). European retail revenue grew 14% with growth in all
territories. There is little detail on its US JV with MGM.
● Synergies likely to be accelerated. As expected, despite the recent agreement
with Playtech, synergy guidance remains unchanged at £130m. However the earlier
platform migration (previous guidance 2021) should allow synergies to be accelerated.
● Balance sheet. ND at y/e of £1,897m (£1,880m) implied ND/EBITDA of 2.5x. Following
shop closures, management is guiding to 3.0x EBITDA for FY19E (NSe 2.9x), before
it begins to delever "by at least 0.5x" p.a. This guidance also includes a further c.£80m
payment to Greek authorities this year in relation to the 2010-2011 tax assessment
(being appealed). In addition, GVC is recognising a charge of £186.8m (32p/share) to
cover its Greek tax liability in relation to 2010-2017.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Current trading and outlook: GVC has reported an "excellent start the year" with
NGR +11% yoy. Online grew 22% which includes c.4ppt net benefit from Crystalbet
and Neds acquisitions less exiting Switzlerland. As a result, management remains
confident in its target of double-digit online NGR growth (NSe +8%). At the group
level, management is "confident of delivering EBITDA ...in-line with expectations" (NSe
£636m EBITDA, consensus £643m) and has committed to minimum annual dividend
growth of 10% (ie at least 36p vs. 34p NSe and consensus).
● Recommendation BUY: With growing market share, top line momentum, geographic
diversification and greater regulatory visibility (eg post-UK Triennial Review), we
believe GVC is uniquely well placed. Trading on 8.9x FY19E EV/EBITDA and 5.2%
dividend yield, we reiterate our BUY recommendation.
